awd_titl_txt: CPS: Breakthrough: Control Improvisation for Cyber-Physical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Inspired by the manner in which humans improvise in everyday life, this NSF project is creating a theory of algorithmic improvisation for cyber-physical systems design. It is developing a mathematical framework, supported by tools, to address the challenge of designing systems that adapt to uncertainty in their operating environment and to changing requirements. Moreover, this framework has broad relevance to many fields in computer science and engineering. Results from the proposed work are being incorporated into teaching, with a particularly strong impact on courses at UC Berkeley on cyber-physical systems and formal methods, and on undergraduate projects conducted under broader outreach programs at UC Berkeley. Additionally, through collaborations with industry partners, the project is improving the state of the art in verification and control in the cyber-physical systems industry.

Uncertainty in the design process, in the behavior of sub-systems that evolve over time, and in the operating environment remains a challenge for CPS design. There is a need to design automatic controllers that improvise to handle challenging situations as a skilled human would. This project addresses this need with a foundation approach that is developing a theoretically-sound definition of algorithmic improvisation that is also grounded in practice. It is exploring the full range of variations of the problem definition, analyzing their computational complexity, and devising efficient algorithms where shown to be theoretically possible. Additionally, it is developing new applications to verification, in novel algorithms for simulation-driven verification and verification of machine learning components, and to control, using improvisation for randomized robot path planning and for controlled exploration in adaptive, learning-based control. Together, this tight combination of theoretical work and practical applications seeks to break new ground in the science of cyber-physical systems.

por.por_cntn:
Inspired by the manner in which humans improvise in everyday life, this NSF
project has created a theory of algorithmic improvisation for cyber-physical
systems (CPS) design. It has developed a mathematical framework, supported by
open-source tools, to address the challenge of designing and verifying systems that adapt to uncertainty in their operating environment and to changing requirements.
The project resulted in the following major accomplishments:

(i) Intellectual Merit: The project has two major technical contributions. The
first concerns novel formal methods for design and analysis of artificial
intelligence (AI) based autonomy in cyber-physical systems. The project contributed
to the creation of Scenic, a new probabilistic programming language for
modeling AI-based autonomous systems and their environments. The conceptual
foundation of Scenic is algorithmic improvisation, wherein Scenic facilitates
the creation of synthetic data subject to hard, soft, and randomness
constraints, for training, testing, and verification of AI based CPS. Scenic,
and its accompanying back-end algorithms implemented in the VerifAI toolkit,
have been successfully demonstrated on industrial-scale systems in the
self-driving car and autonomous avionics domains. The second contribution
comprises a new mathematical framework, termed reactive control improvisation,
for generating randomized strategies for autonomous CPS to navigate in adversarial
environments, with several applications including robotic patrolling against an
adaptive adversary.

(ii) Broader Impacts: Results from the proposed work have had impacts on
teaching, on industrial practice, and on the mentoring of graduate students
and postdoctoral researchers. The open-source Scenic and VerifAI toolkits have
been successfully demonstrated on industrial case studies in the self-driving
and avionics domains, and state of the art industrial autonomous driving
simulators have integrated the Scenic language into their offerings. Graduate
students and postdoctoral researchers supported by the project have obtained
positions in academia and industry. Technology developed in the project has
been used in class projects, incorporated work by undergraduate researchers,
and has contributed to the development of a virtual laboratory infrastructure
used during COVID-19 to teach CPS in a remote setting.
